title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO — On a night when the baskets seemed sealed shut, Michael Jordan provided a masterclass in survival. In a brutal, defensive war that ended 84-71 in favor of the Chicago Bulls, His Airness did not merely score; he *was* the offense, pouring in a staggering 44 points to drag his team to victory against the Cleveland Cavaliers in 1997.

While teammates faltered—Scottie Pippen managed just 9 points—Jordan’s will was the difference. The Cavaliers, led by a gritty 19-point effort from Terrell Brandon, turned the game into a grinding affair. But Jordan was relentless, attacking the rim and hitting from mid-range with a fury that defied the game's sluggish pace. His 44 points were not just a high total; they were a lifeline, accounting for over half of his team's entire offensive output.

The final score, a testament to the defensive struggle, cannot tell the story of Jordan’s singular dominance. This was not a fluid, high-flying Bulls victory; it was a testament to one man's refusal to lose. On a night where points were a premium, Jordan was the sole scorer in a market of drought. He didn't just lead the Bulls; he carried them, ensuring that even on an off-night for the dynasty, the result was never in doubt. It was another historic entry in his legendary career, a performance of pure, unadulterated will.
